title: Wednesday, 12th September 2018
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE11:02am

Morning!

BE11:02am

Hello, hi, welcome, this is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with the etc.

Soundbuy Morning.............
sparrowhawk morning ...
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Ship's company!
sparrowhawk is anything happening here?
BE11:03am

Few things to be getting on with today, including the SSE warning and the latest chapter in Sports Direct's curious relationship with the markets.

VV75 morning
11:03 am
BE11:03am

However .... when was the last time we did this?

BE11:03am

BE11:03am

Been a while, right?

Alchemy30 morning, sure has
Manxish Morning all
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Summer's never the best for grift and rumourtrage.

Stateless Morning
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian Yes, been a while.
BE11:06am

But now people are getting back from their holiday homes in the Dordogne and Tuscany, things begin to wake up again.

BE11:06am

And one of the names they've been talking about on their return is quite surprising.

11:06 am
Fevertree Drinks PLC (FEVR:LSE): Last: 3,934, up 38 (+0.98%), High: 3,936, Low: 3,877, Volume: 254.23k
BE11:06am

So ...............................

BE11:06am

Let's get the caveats up first.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

The first of those is the big sale by founders on August 6: https://www.invest...1808061643039732W/

BE11:08am

The second caveat is a purchase by a non-exec on the same day: https://www.invest...1808061500199635W/

BE11:08am

The third caveat is, of course, Fevertree's nutso valuation. Market cap of £4.6bn-ish, last I checked ............

11:08 am
BE11:09am

.............. but against all that, we've been picking up suggestions of interest in Fevertree from potential bidders.

willosaurus so ... sell the bidders?
VV75 I'm not that surprised, they have the competition looking embarrassed
BE11:10am

With those suggestions of interest taken seriously, meaning Fevertree has passed them over to its broker.

BE11:10am

(House broker is Investec.)

11:10 am
BE11:10am

One potential buyer mentioned in the mix here is PepsiCo.

BE11:11am

Who tend to do their M&A work through Goldman, I think.

BE11:11am

However! More caveats!

willosaurus up loads. lol
11:12 am
BE11:12am

First, PepsiCo tends to be linked with everything. Even if they've had a look, there might be a long distance between "looking" and "bidding".

BE11:12am

Second, PepsiCo's generally understood to be not that keen on Europe.

Sails Fevertree is just sugar water though, with a few flavourings and good marketing. Just shows how much QE_fueled capital there is sloshing around looking for a home
BE11:13am

Oh, and I should also note that there have been rumours of some staff churn at Investec very recently, including people who were involved on the Fevertree float, so that'd be another complication to the story.

Excel Developer How is the world of single stocks today?
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Which, I stress, is very very raw.

Excel Developer Fevertree spiking already.
BE11:15am

Okay, so in terms of background you know the valuation stuff and the US expansion stuff and the increasing competition from various me-too brands stuff ... we've done it often enough.

willosaurus @Excel - fizzing, but gas coming out already?
BE11:16am

Quick bit of Morgan Stanley from July to summarise the bull/bear.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

The US is currently 15% of Fever-Tree sales (FY18e), but we expect it to contribute ~50% of group revenue growth between FY17-22. Based on our proprietary channel checking (details here), conversations with industry players, and Fever-Tree's announcement of an exclusivity agreement with SGWS, we are raising our expectations for premium mixers category growth in the US and our assumptions for Fever-Tree's long term defensible market share within the premium mixers category. We assume the US will overtake the UK as Fever-Tree's largest market in FY22.

Groundhog Day @BE, not to be too negative here, but you only put one line of raw news and 15 caveats. Anything that distinguishes this Fevertree chatter from the usual stuff you get bombarded with? Source particularly trustworthy or so? Thanks a lot, no worries if you cannot say.
BE11:16am

Bull case of £55, or 71 times 2020

BE11:17am

Yep, 71 times.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

In our bull case, the penetration of premium mixers reaches over 30% of the total mixers category across Fever-Tree's main markets by 2025, significantly increasing the Total Addressable Market compared to today. We also expect the development of a cocktail culture in 'ROW' markets to contribute meaningfully by 2025. In our bull case, we see Fever-Tree maintaining its market share position within premium mixers.

Excel Developer my screen says Fevertree already has PE of 86
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian 71 times. Forget it.
tadam PEP is in the process of buying SodaStream, so I don't believe this is likely to be true, makes no sense at all.
Groundhog Day made it move 5% though, so should expect a statement I d say
BE11:18am

(@Groundhog, the "usual stuff" I "get bombarded with" doesn't make it up here. That's the difference.)

BE11:18am

Base case, 54x or £42 (which is nearly where we are).

11:18 am
BE11:18am

We expect strong growth in the premium mixers market. We estimate that
Fever-Tree's Total Addressable Market will grow at ~20% CAGR between 2017-25. Our channel checking gives us confidence that Fever-Tree can defend its position as a market leading premium mixer. In our base case, we expect growth in the UK to remain strong in FY18 (+42%) but see material upside in the US following establishment of wholly owned business and exclusivity agreement with SGWS. Our assumptions for growth in the ROW division are relatively conservative. We set our base case valuation using a DCF approach.

BE11:19am

Bear of £17, which is still 22x 2020.

Groundhog Day @BE thanks
BE11:19am

Which'd still be a massive premium to Britvic, I think .....

chad_john @BE - does this link in any way to what Dan M was saying on here a few months ago re share price pumping via Forums, etc?
11:19 am
BE11:20am

In our bear case Fever-Tree faces intense competition for share of the premium mixers category, and the penetration rate of premium mixers does not reach the same level as the penetration rate of premium spirits. Growth normalises sooner than we or consensus expect, leading to a sharp multiple contraction. However, even if growth does normalise we think that Fever-Tree's attractive business model (asset light, high returns) warrants a premium to the broader staples sector even if the top-line growth outlook does not differ materially.

BE11:20am

Anyway.

Excel Developer I remember SodaStream from childhood. Good idea.
Excel Developer No need to carry water
willosaurus I think I saw a soda stream machine was top seller in Germany on Amazon Prime day last year.
BE11:21am

I emphasise that it's information that's only been lightly frisked and all indications we've had would suggest very very very early stage at best. But I'd also assume that, if Fevertree needed to tell anything to the market, it'd have a duty to do so.

11:21 am
undefined
willosaurus I wonder if they are any good now ... remember being very disappointed as a pop guzzling youth.
BE11:22am

(@chad: what?)

Tom Dalgleish I still believe in the pot gozinta angle on drinks companies
chad_john @BE - I'll find it, it was on a session here a few months ago, give me a sec.
BE11:22am

Okay, what next? There's a FTSE 100 profit warning to get out of the way.

11:22 am
SSE PLC (SSE:LSE): Last: 1,152, down 98.5 (-7.88%), High: 1,171, Low: 1,128, Volume: 6.95m
BE11:23am

Weather, in part.

BE11:23am

A hot, dry and not terribly windy summer takes half the blame here.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

The other half is SSE betting on lower gas prices, and losing.

Close Run Thing Anyone seen/noticed anything interesting on the DVC's being lifted on majority of the FTSE 100 today?
chad_john @BE - It was Neil, sorry: https://ftalphaville.ft.com/marketslive/2018-01-19-2/ - about half way down
BE11:25am

So, significant hit to half-year earnings but the divi guidance is unchanged.

BE11:25am

Meaning the main question relates to how much of this can be considered a one off.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Weather can, undoubtedly. Gas trading being lossmaking, possibly not.

BE11:26am

Jefferies to summarise the numbers.

BE11:27am

Today, SSE has cited that continued pressure from higher gas prices, and
lower renewables output than expected, imply a £190m negative earnings impact for 1H19, compared with planned. This implies a £110m negative impact for 2Q19 (or 10p on FY19 consensus EPS of 112p), with the company already citing a £90m negative earnings impact at its 1Q19 update. However, we highlight that these are weather-driven, non-controllable effects that are likely to be specific to FY19; we see potential negative readacross for Centrica. Encouragingly, the company has confirmed FY19 DPS guidance of 97.5p, and its £1.7bn capex programme for the year.
Detail. Of the £190m negative earnings impact, SSE has indicated that just under half of this is mainly related to higher than expected gas prices, whilst the other half is related to the impact of dry, still and warm weather. With this, SSE currently expects 1H19 operating profit to be half that of 1H18 (£586m).

jaws BE anything in MYSALE GROUP please ? MYSL
11:29 am
BE11:29am

(@chad: to be clear, this is completely unrelated to the random ramp of Fever in January which was on the back of a guessy Motley Fool post. But well done for remembering, you're now our official archivist.)

chad_john @BE It's already on the CV.
BE11:30am

And RBC

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian archivist or stalker?
BE11:30am

Overall we estimate the impact on the full-year adj EBIT, versus current market expectations, will be ~£350m. This is an additional £110m shortfall in H1, plus the continued losses in EPM in H2. This is ~30p on current-year EPS (RBCe 113,5p, consensus 115.6p), before adjusting out the held-for-sale retail operations. What is not clear at this stage is whether the EPM losses will continue into future periods. We expect SSE to react very negatively to this unexpected news, with the reiteration of dividend guidance likely to be the only element of support.

Tom Dalgleish Do we get a Press badge too?
Blue horseshoe... SKY sale hotting up
11:31 am
BE11:32am

Which, fair enough. You buy SSE not because it's exciting but because it'spredictable. The Wholesale division printing random losses undermines that.

BornCynic I can add some raw obtained from a drunk Icelandic person. He stated that Iceland Air was in trouble for not charging enough for their fares.Have fun with that one......
BE11:32am

Sector .....

Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 144.85, down 4.9 (-3.27%), High: 147.55, Low: 143.75, Volume: 10.57m
11:32 am
National Grid PLC (NG.:LSE): Last: 796.20, down 11.7 (-1.45%), High: 804.00, Low: 787.00, Volume: 3.27m
undefined
chad_john @1st Lt. I just recall that being slightly unusual and coinciding with a flurry of activity on certain bulletin boards et al. Probably a bit stalkerish too.
BE11:33am

And so, to Sports Direct.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @chad - Only joking. Good memory!
11:33 am
BE11:33am

And farewell, Keith Hellawell

chad_john ;)
jaws BE anything from BARC note today on builders please ?
Grouchmonkey Morning - sorry I'm late
BE11:35am

Britain's youngest police sergeant, Tony Blair's drugs czar (who resigned over cannabis getting downgraded to Class C) and now ex Ashley.

Penny re Fevertree, does Britvic market premium mixers also?
BE11:36am

ISS and Glass Lewis had both recommended investors vote against his reelection.

Schumacher Give an opportunity to social enterprises!
Grouchmonkey Yes - just launched a range earlier this year, I think.@Penny
11:37 am
BE11:37am

(@Penny: yup, anonymously and as London Essence.)

Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 353.90, up 13 (+3.81%), High: 355.70, Low: 341.70, Volume: 472.09k
Viking1 Any comments on AGK and upcoming storm in the US.In the past has proven to be an interesting trade and short national Grid
BE11:38am

(I meant eponymously, not anonymously! Apologies!)

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Against that we get a vaguely reassuring trading update and a no-show from Ashley at the AGM, apparently.

BE11:40am

Oh, as well as this great statement from The Bishop of Soho late yesterday.

BE11:40am

Clarification regarding FRC

The Company would like to clarify that Sports Direct itself is NOT the subject of an investigation by the FRC, which has jurisdiction over accounting firms and accounting professionals.

Sports Direct is a witness in an FRC investigation, details of which were made public by the FRC on 28 November 2016. This court application relates to the FRC's requests for the provision of certain documents.

Following the handing down of a judgement today in the High Court, Sports Direct obtained leave to appeal certain aspects of the judgement from the judge, and intends to appeal additional aspects of the judgement in due course.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Um, yeah. Who's he clarifying that to?

BE11:42am

We all know the FRC is investigating Sports Direct auditor Grant Thornton for letting the detail slide in the 2016 numbers that Sports Direct was giving cash to a delivery business owned by Ashley's older brother.

BE11:44am

Which in a technical sense does indeed mean that Sports Direct isn't "the subject" of the investigation. However, when you've just been ordered in court to turn over emails to that investigation, it's fair to suggest you're directly involved as something more than merely a witness.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Anyway ......

BE11:44am

Have Liberum buying Sports Direct.

BE11:44am

Today's brief AGM update reiterates guidance for 5% to 15% underlying EBITDA growth in FY19E (y/e April), excluding the House of Fraser acquisition. We also note yesterday's statement from the company clarifying that Sports Direct itself is not the subject of an investigation by the FRC. Set against this newsflow, we see yesterday's 5% share price fall as unjustified. Further, the 22% fall since the group's strong prelims in July is unwarranted, in our view. The shares currently trade on a FY19 PER of 16.2x and EV/EBITDA of 7.2x.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

And on the HoF ....

BE11:45am

We think Sport Direct's acquisition of HoF could prove to be a shrewd strategic move. At the prelims in July, management clearly highlighted its intentions to align its wider apparel credentials with its significant relationships in footwear to develop a broader offer that strengthens appeal across the UK fashion market. This forms part of a top-down strategy, through the group’s Premium Lifestyle and Sport Retail divisions, which flows from luxury (Flannels), down to premium (Cruise, van mildert) and to mass-market (USC, Sports Direct), as well the group’s more nascent discount designer outlet stores (Brand Max).

HoF’s business, including its strong strategic relationships for which it has become so well know, can broaden SPD’s brand relationships and make it a more significant player across all areas of the UK clothing market. It includes some very attractive store locations which can support SPD’s multi-channel “Elevation Strategy”. Importantly, the benefits could flow both ways with House of Fraser benefitting from SPD’s broad relationships, including its more fashion focused offerings (Flannels, Cruise, van mildert).

BE11:46am

Sports Direct non-exec Simon Bentley is on the tape saying the board discussed combining House of Fraser with Debenhams, BTW.

11:46 am
Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 12.35, up 0.0795 (+0.65%), High: 12.73, Low: 12.19, Volume: 2.21m
Excel Developer House of Debs? "Frabenhams"?
VV75 Debs Direct
BE11:49am

The wording makes it sound like it's an idea that's been and gone, and you have to question how some of the details would be bashed out .... such as the 50% or so of floorspace that'd need removed ......

undefined
11:49 am
BE11:49am

Request for Barclays on the housebuilders.

BE11:50am

It's slightly dull, though I did my best to summarise it over here: https://www.ft.com...-bbc3-ccd7de085ffe

Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 169.10, up 1.3 (+0.77%), High: 170.85, Low: 168.35, Volume: 4.85m
Tom Dalgleish Logo 2 drunks propped apart by a bottle

chad_john "House of Debenhams" has an interesting ring to it

Pullback over the past year or so has taken it back to fair value, assuming HTB is now considered a lode-bearing policy for the Conservatives despite the damage it's doing to the housing market. That's the argument.

Tom Dalgleish Is that to sportify HOF? How is that salvation of a department store?
BE11:54am

(Another plug for Simon French's excellent HtB summary in the Times last week: https://www.thetim...y-market-zrnqrp3zx )

Tom Dalgleish Is it to absolutely slay the sports gear segment?
11:54 am
Bovis Homes Group PLC (BVS:LSE): Last: 1,140, up 9.5 (+0.84%), High: 1,158, Low: 1,130, Volume: 167.39k
Pharma Dystopian nightmare: Nationwide rollout of Lillywhites in old HoF & Deb sites.
BE11:55am

D
espite
persistent
political and economic
headwinds
, current trading has remained
robust for the most part.
With some shares down by as much as 35% from their late October highs, we believe these headwinds are largely priced in and we restore neutrality to our stock ratings, raising Taylor Wimpey to OW (from EW) and Bovis Homes to EW (from UW). We downgrade Crest Nicholson to EW (from OW) to reflect more challenging conditions in the company’s southern footprint

Sails House of Debs sounds like some 1950s debutantes being presented to the Queen flashback
BE11:55am

Oh, that's come out as concrete poetry. Interesting.

jaws BE thank you for builders info.
nickcar jaws is here as well
The Early Bird Morning all
Tom Dalgleish and is it to practise brand denial to competing store?
11:56 am
BE11:57am

Help to Buy remains a key pillar of support, protecting much of the new - build sector from wider trends. Government assistance is likely to stay strong, given malcontent among the young (evident at the last Election) and we expect a scheme extension, with ‘tweaks’, to be announced this year. In the longer term, ‘part own, part rent’ schemes – which have gained prominence in the last 12 - 18 months – could offer a viable alternative

Pharma HtB must be linked to the survival or otherwise of May. If May goes, so does Hammond, and I would imagine HtB with him.
BE11:59am

Mortgages cheap but build costs stubbornly high, particularly down south. Land market's fine apart from in commuter belt London and a few hotspots in Scotland and the Midlands

Pharma (HtB being Help the Builders, of course).
nickcar without immigrant labour housebuild costs would be even more
BE12:00pm

Letwin review does nothing, planning system remains Kafkian and Stamp Duty hinders the top end. You know the arguments here. Let's cut to valuations.

Excel Developer Don't expect rationality from the party that gave you Brexit.
Tom Dalgleish Kafkaesque?
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

We use a three - year FCF model to value the builders, and roll our reference period forward by a year to 2018 - 2020. We also make changes to our applied yields, raising them (by 100bps for most, and by 250 - 350bps for McCarthy & Stone and Crest Nicholson) to capture our view of heightened risks . Following a period of positive momentum, consensus earnings forecasts have flattened out (and in some cases turned negative). However, we believe much of this is priced in and, with share prices down by as much as 35 % from their late October highs, we restore neutrality to our ratings set.

undefined
BE12:03pm

(Tom: yeah, that's what I meant. Though Kafkian seems to be acceptable as well.)

Tom Dalgleish BErilliant
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Okay, that'll do for Wednesday.

Tom Dalgleish If SPD can pull of a HOF turnaround its a useful template
VV75 thanks
Soundbuy Cheers.......
BE12:06pm

Ta for tuning in, and for the comments.

BE12:07pm

Back tomorrow, and tomorrow, and tomorrow creeps in this petty pace from day to day to the last syllable of recorded time.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Afternoon all.
